metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: AngularJS Directives
AngularJS lets you extend HTML with new attributes called Directives .
content.html: AngularJS lets you extend HTML with new attributes called Directives.

content.text: AngularJS has a set of built-in directives which offers functionality to your applications.
content.html: AngularJS has a set of built-in directives which offers functionality to your applications.

content.text: AngularJS also lets you define your own directives.
content.html: AngularJS also lets you define your own directives.

content.text: AngularJS Directives
AngularJS directives are extended HTML attributes with the prefix ng- .
content.html: AngularJS directives are extended HTML attributes with the prefix ng-.

content.text: The ng-app directive initializes an AngularJS application.
content.html: The ng-app directive initializes an AngularJS application.

content.text: The ng-init directive initializes application data.
content.html: The ng-init directive initializes application data.

content.text: The ng-model directive binds the value of HTML controls (input, select, textarea) to application data.
content.html: The ng-model directive binds the value of HTML controls (input, select, textarea) to application data.

content.text: Read about all AngularJS directives in our AngularJS directive reference .
content.html: Read about all AngularJS directives in our AngularJS directive reference.

content.code:
Name:

You wrote: {{ firstName }}
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="" ng-init="firstName='John'">

<p>Name: <input type="text" ng-model="firstName"></p>
<p>You wrote: {{ firstName }}</p>

</div>

content.text: The ng-app directive also tells AngularJS that the <div> element is the "owner" of the AngularJS application.
content.html: The ng-app directive also tells AngularJS that the <div> element is the "owner" of the AngularJS application.

content.text: Data Binding
The {{ firstName }} expression, in the example above, is an AngularJS data binding expression.
content.html: The {{ firstName }} expression, in the example above, is an AngularJS data binding expression.

content.text: Data binding in AngularJS binds AngularJS expressions with AngularJS data.
content.html: Data binding in AngularJS binds AngularJS expressions with AngularJS data.

content.text: {{ firstName }} is bound with ng-model="firstName" .
content.html: {{ firstName }} is bound with ng-model="firstName".

content.text: In the next example two text fields are bound together with two ng-model directives:
content.html: In the next example two text fields are bound together with two ng-model directives:

content.code: Quantity: Costs: Total in dollar:{{ quantity * price }}
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="" ng-init="quantity=1;price=5">

Quantity: <input type="number" ng-model="quantity">
Costs:    <input type="number" ng-model="price">

Total in dollar: {{ quantity * price }}

</div>

content.text: Using ng-init is not very common. You will learn how to initialize data in the chapter about controllers.
content.html: Using ng-init is not very common. You will learn how to initialize data in the chapter about controllers.

content.text: Repeating HTML Elements
The ng-repeat directive repeats an HTML element:
content.html: The ng-repeat directive repeats an HTML element:

content.code: •       {{ x }}
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="" ng-init="names=['Jani','Hege','Kai']">
  <ul>
    <li ng-repeat="x in names">
      {{ x }}
    </li>
  </ul>
</div>

content.text: The ng-repeat directive actually clones HTML elements once for each item in a collection.
content.html: The ng-repeat directive actually clones HTML elements once for each item in a collection.

content.text: The ng-repeat directive used on an array of objects:
content.html: The ng-repeat directive used on an array of objects:

content.code: • {{ x.name + ', ' + x.country }}
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="" ng-init="names=[
{name:'Jani',country:'Norway'},
{name:'Hege',country:'Sweden'},
{name:'Kai',country:'Denmark'}]">

<ul>
  <li ng-repeat="x in names">
    {{ x.name + ', ' + x.country }}
  </li>
</ul>

</div>

content.text: AngularJS is perfect for database CRUD (Create Read Update Delete) applications. Just imagine if these objects were records from a database.
content.html:
AngularJS is perfect for database CRUD (Create Read Update Delete) applications.
Just imagine if these objects were records from a database.

content.text: The ng-app Directive
The ng-app directive defines the root element of an AngularJS application.
content.html: The ng-app directive defines the root element of an AngularJS application.

content.text: The ng-app directive will auto-bootstrap (automatically initialize) the application when a web page is loaded.
content.html: The ng-app directive will auto-bootstrap (automatically initialize) the application when a web page is loaded.

content.text: The ng-init Directive
The ng-init directive defines initial values for an AngularJS application.
content.html: The ng-init directive defines initial values for an AngularJS application.

content.text: Normally, you will not use ng-init. You will use a controller or module instead.
content.html: Normally, you will not use ng-init. You will use a controller or module instead.

content.text: You will learn more about controllers and modules later.
content.html: You will learn more about controllers and modules later.

content.text: The ng-model Directive
The ng-model directive binds the value of HTML controls (input, select, textarea) to application data.
content.html: The ng-model directive binds the value of HTML controls (input, select, textarea) to application data.

content.text: The ng-model directive can also:
content.html: The ng-model directive can also:

content.text: Read more about the ng-model directive in the next chapter.
content.html: Read more about the ng-model directive in the next chapter.

content.text: Create New Directives
In addition to all the built-in AngularJS directives, you can create your own directives.
content.html: In addition to all the built-in AngularJS directives, you can create your own directives.

content.text: New directives are created by using the .directive function.
content.html: New directives are created by using the .directive function.

content.text: To invoke the new directive, make an HTML element with the same tag name as the new directive.
content.html: To invoke the new directive, make an HTML element with the same tag name as the new directive.

content.text: When naming a directive, you must use a camel case name, w3TestDirective , but when invoking it, you must use - separated name, w3-test-directive :
content.html: When naming a directive, you must use a camel case name, w3TestDirective, but when invoking it, you must use - separated name, w3-test-directive:

content.code_html:
<body ng-app="myApp">

<w3-test-directive></w3-test-directive>

<script>
var app = angular.module("myApp", []);
app.directive("w3TestDirective", function() {
  return {
    template : "<h1>Made by a directive!</h1>"
  };
});
</script>

</body>

content.text: You can invoke a directive by using:
content.html: You can invoke a directive by using:

content.text: The examples below will all produce the same result:
content.html: The examples below will all produce the same result:

content.code_html: <w3-test-directive></w3-test-directive>
<div w3-test-directive></div>
<div class="w3-test-directive"></div>
<!-- directive: w3-test-directive -->

content.text: Restrictions
You can restrict your directives to only be invoked by some of the methods.
content.html: You can restrict your directives to only be invoked by some of the methods.

content.code_html:
var app = angular.module("myApp", []);
app.directive("w3TestDirective", function() {
  return {
    restrict : "A",
    template : "<h1>Made by a directive!</h1>"
  };
});

content.text: The legal restrict values are:
content.html: The legal restrict values are:

content.text: By default the value is EA , meaning that both Element names and attribute names can invoke the directive.
content.html: By default the value is EA, meaning that both Element names and attribute names can invoke the directive.
